skin_cancers.description: A common and slow-growing form of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells in the epidermis. Often appears as a pearly or waxy bump, a flat flesh-colored lesion, or a sore that doesn't heal.
next_steps: Consult a dermatologist for a biopsy
Follow up with regular skin checks
Use sun protection to prevent recurrence

skin_cancers.description: A skin cancer that arises from squamous cells in the outer layer of the skin. It can appear as a scaly red patch, an open sore, or a wart-like growth and may bleed or crust over.
next_steps: Consult a dermatologist for a biopsy
Determine the stage of cancer if advanced
Regular follow-ups to monitor for recurrence

skin_cancers.description: A dangerous form of skin cancer that originates in the pigment-producing melanocytes. It often appears as a new or changing mole with asymmetry, irregular borders, color variations, a diameter larger than 6mm, and evolving features.
treatment: Sentinel lymph node biopsy if advanced
Radiation or chemotherapy in advanced cases
next_steps: Treatment plan based on stage and mutation status
Routine skin checks for early detection of recurrence

skin_cancers.description: A rare but aggressive skin cancer that arises from Merkel cells in the skin. It often appears as a firm, painless, rapidly growing red or purple nodule.
next_steps: Urgent evaluation by a dermatologist or oncologist
Imaging scans to check for spread

skin_cancers.description: A precancerous condition caused by long-term sun exposure. It appears as rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas and has the potential to develop into squamous cell carcinoma.
next_steps: Treatment to prevent progression to cancer
